Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 07:03AM EWB wrote: JoJo, good to hear from you. Sounds like you are doing all the right things, thinking and talking about the options. I think it was mentioned in an earlier post...just because you decline the traditional, potentially harsh treatment approach, doesn't mean there aren't other things out there that you can look into. Simple changes in diet and activity can help you feel well, pallative care (which is not necessarily hopsice related) is all about managing effects and side effects so you feel as well as possible, all kinds of meditation, prayer, reflexology/rekei/massage, tai chi and so on and so on. Always remember that declining traditional treatment does not mean instant death.  On a more cheerful note- I have to say I love the name JoJo Potatoes...its just fun to say...I am easily amused as you can see. Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2008 09:13AM - edited Dec 4, 2008 09:15AM by EWB ladyjane- I have no experience with hair loss but your situation made me think of something my daughter went thru when she was 5 and thought I would share it. During preschool the Telephone Pioneers did eye screenings for the preschoolers.  Since everyone in my family has glasses (me from the age of 2) we were expecting results that would send us to eye doctor.  Sure enough, vision in one eye was 20/400..the eye doc said she problably has never really used the eye at all.  Needless to say she was given glasses and had to wear an eyepatch for all but one hour of her awake time during the day. Even at 5 she understood and was not happy abouit it and was very worried abouit what the other children would say.  Dr was great and suggested that we have fun with it and decorate the eye patches.  Every night before bed we would discuss the next day and decide on decorations (often to match activity of the day) bugs for bug day, swimmer for pool opening day etc.  Some were stickers but most were drawn on.  Even had a special box.  Explained to her that the eye was lazy and taking a vacation so we had to make it work with the patch (since eyeballs can't lift weights) and allow the strong eye a vacation.  We had a week during Easter break to get use to this at home, had spoken to preschool teacher before opening day.  Teacher was great and the class talked about it first thing, allowing kids to ask questions etc.  Reaction by most of the children was---why can't I have one.   Anyway- the point of my long story was that it was someting that had to be done and we had fun with it.One day we decided to trick people and drew an eye on her patch and everyone thought she wasn't wearing the patch. The children will follow your lead in how to react to it all. I can't image the experience of hair loss and how I would feel about it but I think and hope I would be able to do what we did with Caity and have fun--wigs, scarves, hats, head doodles.  For me it would give ME the control.   I wish you all the best and keep you in my prayers...Elaine

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 02:59PM EWB wrote: I was dxed with stage 4 bc w/ mets to spine. I did not have surgery, chemo or rads. Went straight to hormonal (Femara, w/Lupron since I am not post meno). My onc has same idea to hold off on chemo until its needed.. until this stops working. The idea is to have the lowest amount of drugs, while still effective and string along treatments for as long as possible. It has been 3 years, there has been no progression and some improvement in a few spots. It is a newer thought process and very different from what I expected, but has been very effective. Best wishes in your decision and treatment!

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2010 10:30AM EWB wrote: Oh sweetie - I am in a similar situation...its easy to say kick him out, divorce him etc but not so easy. Depends on what state you live in, how long you were married, working, taking care of children etc. There are complicating factors (at least for me)...I am on disability, I NEED insurance, list goes on. What I have discovered is that this was HIS choice, not mine, and he will and has rewritten history to justify what he has done and is doing.  Know that this is NOT YOUR FAULT...this is about him and what ever odd things are going on in his head...most of which probably makes no sense to anyone else but him. Think adolescence in an adult male, midlife transition or midlife crisis. Most hospitals have counselors and social workers that you can talk to (or as I did cry at) and can help you work out what to do...what is best for you and your situation.  My heart goes out to you and I wish you only the very best!!

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 11:35PM EWB wrote: I can't speak for others but my concern is just having a place where I can speak out my fears, concerns, etc as they relate to a stage 4 dx. I want to be able to talk openly about death, dying, fear of what is coming next, what if the meds that are keeping me stable stop working....and not have to worry that some one at an earlier stage will be bothered or concerned about it. I feel often like I (we) have to walk on eggshells, being concerned about how others will react to the darker side of cancer, or the dark humor that hits some days, or the open, frank language that might be used. Sort of defeats the purpose of a support or discussion bd. It shouldn't be this hard. One dx or stage is not better or worse than another, just different with each one having its own set of demons. There is a place for everyone, I just ask for a place where I can openly share with others who share the same dx and situation. Elaine

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 06:36PM EWB wrote: No such thing as a stupid question! In addition to the ovaries (which is biggest producer of estrogen) the adrenal gland is also involved in producing/converting estrogren.  For anyone with estrogen positive cancer (meaning the cancer needs estrogen to grow) being able to cut off as much estrogen becomes important.  This is where AIs, tamoxofin come into play.  For those who are premenopausal, some oncs will induce menopause chemically (ie Lupron) or surgically and use AIs. Since estrogen has a role in joint/muscle health--cutting off all or most estrogen can cause joint stiffness or pain.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 08:42PM EWB wrote: So sorry for all the aches and pains! Lord knows its not fun.... I have been on Femara and Lupron for about 3 yrs now and unfortunately have not adjusted to the meds. Lots of aches. I believe many of the side effects are caused by the very low/no estrogen - remember that in addition to losing the estrogen produced by the ovaries, we are also losing estrogren converted by the adrenal gland (AIs) so this is not "just menopause" its what my dh likes to call "menopause on steroids".  Non-AI menopause ladies still have that little bit. Estrogen is involved with so much more than "babies and girlie stuff" Between that and other treatments, surgeries you might have had, the stress of life w/cancer, stress of life in general, caring for small children etc is enough to cause real problems. So glad you are going to see onc soon - always better safe than sorry -  lymphodema is not something you want to play around with! Very gentle hugs to everyone and hopes for an ache free day. Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 10:50AM EWB wrote: Lisa- ooph is oopherectomy which is the surgical procedure that removes the ovaries. The AIs are blocking or stopping the conversion of androgen to estrogen; this is done mostly in the adrenal glands and some in muscle and fat cells. This estrogen supply is not the highest amount in your system, that comes from the ovaries. This is why AIs are used for post meno women (whether naturally, chemo, medically or surgically induced) to help reduce whatever estrogen conversion is left after the ovaries are turned off. For some (like me) they are giving me lupron to deal with the ovaries and then Femara to deal with the rest.

When I was running a food pantry, I would get these calls from parents in a panic --they had NO food in the house and needed help immediately but has no $, no car no gas etc.  As I spoke with these ladies, what almost always came out was... well yes they had bread and well yes there were some cans of soups & veggies and well yes they had a lg jar of peanut butter and well yes there was some powdered milk that could be made up...bottom line was there was food (usually enough for 3-5 days) but it wasn't what they felt like, or not their favorite. I imagine all of us, at different times in our lives and marriages have hard times to get thru, choices that have to be made. No one said it was always fun being a grownup, it sounds like they are not yet taking responsibility for their circumstances... much like my formerly dh nothing is his fault, its always someone else's fault, always an excuse, responsibility always always rests elsewhere. Hang tough, take care of you and Ed, document everything and things will work out ok in the end (if its not ok, then its not the end!!!)

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 08:59PM - edited Oct 20, 2009 09:02PM by EWB Oh sweetie! I so wish I could take this from you... it is an awful place to be.  I won't say don't worry and all that kind of stuff, cause we all know that won't happen. I will say there are many wonderful women on this site with loads and loads of wisdom and knowledge. I will also say 1.  remember to breathe,  2.  you can and will get thru this, just take it one day at a time or if you need to go 15 mins at a time- you can do anything for 15 minutes    3.  Right now be sure to take care of yourself. Treat yourself as you would a good friend -- be kind, be gentle -- be understanding -- be patient -- be good to yourself!   4.  In many cases, you have a little more time than you think to start treatment -- take the time to make the best choice for you and your situation. Don't let anyone talk you into something if it feels really wrong -- get second opinions, ask questions, do research, ask more questions until you understand. 5.  be careful of "the internet" .... Mostly-- love your self. Come here with questions, for answers, hugs, support, to cry and be afraid, to laugh (yes that will come again), to share good and bad things and to be with others who get it and have been where you are right now. It will be ok.
